elements.content: The design of multianionic chelating ligands as new organic linker for producing metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) is discussed. Three potentially polyanionic pro-ligands, 3,5-di-tert-butyl-2-hydroxy-N-(2-hydroxyethyl)benzamide (1LH3), bis(2-aminoethyl)-5-(tert-butyl)-2-hydroxyisophthalate (2aLH3), and 5-(tert-butyl)-2-hydroxy-N1,N3-bis(1-hydroxy-2-methylpropan-2-yl)isophthalamide (2bLH3), were synthesized and found to coordinate the osmyl ion in trianionic NO2 fashion through the N-amidate, O-phenolate, and O-alcoholate donor atoms. The X-ray crystal structures of three dioxo-Os(VI) complexes: [Os2O4(1L)2(OH)K2(H2O)(C3H6O)] (Os 1 ), [OsO2(2aL3–)(MeOH)4(MeO)K2] (Os 2a ), and [OsO2(2bL)(H2O)(C3H6O)K] (Os 2b ) reveal that the osmyl moiety and the ligand establish distinctive interactions with the potassium ions, yielding unprecedented infinite network from stepladder chain (in Os 2b ) and 2D-grid (in Os 1 ) to 3D-porous H-bonding network (in Os 2a ).
elements.clean_text: The design of multianionic chelating ligands as new organic linker for producing metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) is discussed. Three potentially polyanionic pro-ligands, 3,5-di-tert-butyl-2-hydroxy-N-(2-hydroxyethyl)benzamide (1LH3), bis(2-aminoethyl)-5-(tert-butyl)-2-hydroxyisophthalate (2aLH3), and 5-(tert-butyl)-2-hydroxy-N1,N3-bis(1-hydroxy-2-methylpropan-2-yl)isophthalamide (2bLH3), were synthesized and found to coordinate the osmyl ion in trianionic NO2 fashion through the N-amidate, O-phenolate, and O-alcoholate donor atoms. The X-ray crystal structures of three dioxo-Os(VI) complexes: [Os2O4(1L)2(OH)K2(H2O)(C3H6O)] (Os  1 ), [OsO2(2aL3-)(MeOH)4(MeO)K2] (Os  2a ), and [OsO2(2bL)(H2O)(C3H6O)K] (Os  2b ) reveal that the osmyl moiety and the ligand establish distinctive interactions with the potassium ions, yielding unprecedented infinite network from stepladder chain (in Os  2b ) and 2D-grid (in Os  1 ) to 3D-porous H-bonding network (in Os  2a ).

elements.content: The design of multianionic chelating pro-ligands as new organic linkers for producing metal−organic frameworks (MOFs) is discussed. Three salicylamide pro-ligands were synthesized and found to coordinate to osmyl ion in trianionic NO2 fashion through the N-amidate, O-phenolate, and O-alcoholate donor atoms. X-ray crystal structures of three dioxo-Os(VI) complexes are reported, yielding unprecedented infinite K/Os networks from stepladder chain (in Os 2b ) and 2D-grid (in Os 1 ) to 3D-porous H-bonding network (in Os 2a ).
elements.clean_text: The design of multianionic chelating pro-ligands as new organic linkers for producing metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) is discussed. Three salicylamide pro-ligands were synthesized and found to coordinate to osmyl ion in trianionic NO2 fashion through the N-amidate, O-phenolate, and O-alcoholate donor atoms. X-ray crystal structures of three dioxo-Os(VI) complexes are reported, yielding unprecedented infinite K/Os networks from stepladder chain (in Os  2b ) and 2D-grid (in Os  1 ) to 3D-porous H-bonding network (in Os  2a ).

elements.content: The design of metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) has attracted wide attention in recent years because of their potential applications for hydrogen storage, gas separation, catalysis, and molecular recognition. In particular, in catalysis, MOF can create a microconfinment that may be advantageous in increasing the efficiency and selectivity of the catalyst. Neutral oxo-Os(VI) complexes bearing porphyrin, salen, and other dianionic ligands have shown notable ability to promote the oxidation of alkenes (e.g., hydroxylation, dihydroxylation, epoxidation, C–C bond cleavage), as well as benzyl alcohol (to benzaldehyde). Therefore, oxo-Os(VI) complexes may have potential applications in oxidation catalysis. While osmium-based MOFs are scarce, MOFs containing trans-dioxoosmium(VI) (osmyl) entities are absent. Due to the neutral charge of most of the trans-dioxoosmium(VI) complexes reported, the intermolecular interactions to form infinite network are not achievable in these compounds and only discrete complexes have been obtained. Collins et al. have explored Os chemistry with polyanionic ligands; however, negatively charged dioxoosmium(VI) complexes have not been structurally determined and little is known about the possible intermolecular interaction of the [OsO2]2+ entities. Herein, we show that the use of the potentially trianionic salicylamide pro-ligands 1LH3, 2aLH3, and 2bLH3 (Scheme ) leads to unprecedented negatively charged osmyl complexes (Os 1 , Os 2a , and Os 2b respectively), the interactions of which with coordinating K+ ions yield Os/K infinite networks. Despite the similarities of the pro-ligands used and their identical coordination mode to osmyl ion, the obtained structures are different from one another. Thus, while Os 2b consists of stepladder chains, Os 1 gives rise to a 2D-grid network, and Os 2a is best described as a 3D-porous material formed by H-bonding between 2D-MOF sheets. These differences are the result of diverse interactions of the polyanionic complex with the potassium ions.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

The design of metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) has attracted wide attention in recent years because of their potential applications for hydrogen storage, gas separation, catalysis, and molecular recognition. In particular, in catalysis, MOF can create a microconfinment that may be advantageous in increasing the efficiency and selectivity of the catalyst. Neutral oxo-Os(VI) complexes bearing porphyrin, salen, and other dianionic ligands have shown notable ability to promote the oxidation of alkenes (e.g., hydroxylation, dihydroxylation, epoxidation, C-C bond cleavage), as well as benzyl alcohol (to benzaldehyde). Therefore, oxo-Os(VI) complexes may have potential applications in oxidation catalysis. While osmium-based MOFs are scarce, MOFs containing trans-dioxoosmium(VI) (osmyl) entities are absent. Due to the neutral charge of most of the trans-dioxoosmium(VI) complexes reported, the intermolecular interactions to form infinite network are not achievable in these compounds and only discrete complexes have been obtained. Collins et al. have explored Os chemistry with polyanionic ligands; however, negatively charged dioxoosmium(VI) complexes have not been structurally determined and little is known about the possible intermolecular interaction of the [OsO2]2+ entities. Herein, we show that the use of the potentially trianionic salicylamide pro-ligands 1LH3, 2aLH3, and 2bLH3 (Scheme ) leads to unprecedented negatively charged osmyl complexes (Os  1 , Os  2a , and Os  2b  respectively), the interactions of which with coordinating K+ ions yield Os/K infinite networks. Despite the similarities of the pro-ligands used and their identical coordination mode to osmyl ion, the obtained structures are different from one another. Thus, while Os  2b  consists of stepladder chains, Os  1  gives rise to a 2D-grid network, and Os  2a  is best described as a 3D-porous material formed by H-bonding between 2D-MOF sheets. These differences are the result of diverse interactions of the polyanionic complex with the potassium ions.

elements.clean_text: 1  Pro-ligands 1LH3, 2aLH3, and 2bLH3

elements.content: Pro-ligand 1LH3 was synthesized as previously reported. The synthesis of 2bLH3 was successfully achieved in an analogue manner to 2aLH3, i.e., in three steps starting from the phenol-protected diacid precursor 5-(tert-butyl)-2-methoxyisophthalic acid [see ]. Each pro-ligand reacts with freshly prepared K2[Os(OH)4(O)2] in methanol in a 1:1 ratio to give the corresponding yellow-brown complexes Os 1 , Os 2a , and Os 2b in high yields (74–92%) (see ). TGA analysis indicates that these three compounds are stable at least up to 260 °C with only ca. 10–12% weight loss attributed to solvent loss (see ). The IR spectra of the three compounds display an intense ν(OsO) stretching vibration in the range of 825–842 cm–1 confirming the presence of the osmyl moiety in solid state. Single crystals of Os 1 , Os 2a , and Os 2b suitable for X-ray crystallography were obtained and their X-ray structures revealed polymeric networks of formula [Os2O4(1L)2(OH)K2(H2O)(C3H6O)], [OsO2(2aL3–)(MeOH)4(MeO)K2], and [OsO2(2bL)(H2O)(C3H6O)K], respectively (see , Figures –). These three compounds represent the first crystallographically characterized examples of trans-dioxoosmium(VI) derivatives bearing polyanionic salicylamidate ligands. All three compounds possess the following common features. (a) Each osmium center has an octahedral coordination sphere containing a trans-dioxo-osmium(VI) moiety with characteristic OsO bond distances in the range 1.734–1.757 Å. (b) Each osmyl moiety is ligated by three O- and one N-atom donors in a square planar fashion constituting the base of the octahedron. (c) Each ligand coordinates the Os ion in a trianionic NO2 planar fashion through the N-amidate, O-phenolate, and O-alcoholate donor atoms with bond lengths in the ranges: 1.948–1.977 Å (Os–N), 1.995–2.026 Å (Os–O(phenolate)), and 1.997–2.168 Å for Os–O(alcoholate). The octahedron around the osmium is completed by an O atom donor from a water (in Os 2b ), an hydroxyl or a μ-alkoxo- (in Os 1 ), or a methanol (in Os 2a ) molecule. (d) Each complex is negatively charged and establishes coordinative interaction with the K+ ion.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Synthesis and General Characterization of New Osmium Complexes

Pro-ligand 1LH3 was synthesized as previously reported. The synthesis of 2bLH3 was successfully achieved in an analogue manner to 2aLH3, i.e., in three steps starting from the phenol-protected diacid precursor 5-(tert-butyl)-2-methoxyisophthalic acid [see ]. Each pro-ligand reacts with freshly prepared K2[Os(OH)4(O)2] in methanol in a 1:1 ratio to give the corresponding yellow-brown complexes Os  1 , Os  2a , and Os  2b  in high yields (74-92%) (see ). TGA analysis indicates that these three compounds are stable at least up to 260 °C with only ca. 10-12% weight loss attributed to solvent loss (see ). The IR spectra of the three compounds display an intense ν(OsO) stretching vibration in the range of 825-842 cm-1 confirming the presence of the osmyl moiety in solid state. Single crystals of Os  1 , Os  2a , and Os  2b  suitable for X-ray crystallography were obtained and their X-ray structures revealed polymeric networks of formula [Os2O4(1L)2(OH)K2(H2O)(C3H6O)], [OsO2(2aL3-)(MeOH)4(MeO)K2], and [OsO2(2bL)(H2O)(C3H6O)K], respectively (see , Figures    -). These three compounds represent the first crystallographically characterized examples of trans-dioxoosmium(VI) derivatives bearing polyanionic salicylamidate ligands. All three compounds possess the following common features. (a) Each osmium center has an octahedral coordination sphere containing a trans-dioxo-osmium(VI) moiety with characteristic OsO bond distances in the range 1.734-1.757 Å. (b) Each osmyl moiety is ligated by three O- and one N-atom donors in a square planar fashion constituting the base of the octahedron. (c) Each ligand coordinates the Os ion in a trianionic NO2 planar fashion through the N-amidate, O-phenolate, and O-alcoholate donor atoms with bond lengths in the ranges: 1.948-1.977 Å (Os-N), 1.995-2.026 Å (Os-O(phenolate)), and 1.997-2.168 Å for Os-O(alcoholate). The octahedron around the osmium is completed by an O atom donor from a water (in Os  2b ), an hydroxyl or a μ-alkoxo- (in Os  1 ), or a methanol (in Os  2a ) molecule. (d) Each complex is negatively charged and establishes coordinative interaction with the K+ ion.

elements.content: Despite these common features, in each anionic complex, the osmyl moiety as well as the ligand establish distinctive interactions with the potassium ions leading to the formation of unprecedented infinite networks from bundle chain (in Os 2b ), 2D-grid (in Os 1 ), to porous 3D H-bonded framework (in Os 2a ).
elements.clean_text: Despite these common features, in each anionic complex, the osmyl moiety as well as the ligand establish distinctive interactions with the potassium ions leading to the formation of unprecedented infinite networks from bundle chain (in Os  2b ), 2D-grid (in Os  1 ), to porous 3D H-bonded framework (in Os  2a ).

elements.content: The phenol-diamide pro-ligand 2bLH3 possesses two ethanolamine pendant arms; one pendant arm is fully deprotonated and coordinated to osmium(VI) ion in a planar NO2 fashion, the phenolate and alcoholate O-donor atoms being in trans-position with respect to each other. These two O atoms (O3 and O1, Figure A) serve as the point of connection with K+ ions at both extremities of the complex. That way, two osmium blocks connect through two potassium ions giving rise to a quasi-planar K2Os2O4 eight-membered ring (Figure A) with cross-ring distances of 5.412 Å (OsOs), 5.666 Å (KK). This structure is maintained by further coordination of the K+ ion by the alcohol pendant arm O5 (K1–O5 2.746(4) Å) (Figure A) and the osmyl O atom O7 (K1–O7 2.902 Å). In addition, the dimer structure is further stabilized by the formation of H-bonding between two osmyl units (Figure A). Thus, one osmyl O atom is H-bonded to the water molecule bound to the other Os ion (i.e., OsO···H2O–Os H-bonding), and vice versa, yielding a unique Os2O4 6-membered ring motif. This H-bonding is evidenced by the O···H–O angle of 160(6)° and the O···O bond distance of 2.035 Å.
elements.clean_text:
[OsO2(2bL)(H2O)(C3H6O)K], Os  2b  

The phenol-diamide pro-ligand 2bLH3 possesses two ethanolamine pendant arms; one pendant arm is fully deprotonated and coordinated to osmium(VI) ion in a planar NO2 fashion, the phenolate and alcoholate O-donor atoms being in trans-position with respect to each other. These two O atoms (O3 and O1, Figure A) serve as the point of connection with K+ ions at both extremities of the complex. That way, two osmium blocks connect through two potassium ions giving rise to a quasi-planar K2Os2O4 eight-membered ring (Figure A) with cross-ring distances of 5.412 Å (OsOs), 5.666 Å (KK). This structure is maintained by further coordination of the K+ ion by the alcohol pendant arm O5 (K1-O5 2.746(4) Å) (Figure A) and the osmyl O atom O7 (K1-O7 2.902 Å). In addition, the dimer structure is further stabilized by the formation of H-bonding between two osmyl units (Figure A). Thus, one osmyl O atom is H-bonded to the water molecule bound to the other Os ion (i.e., OsO⋅⋅⋅H2O-Os H-bonding), and vice versa, yielding a unique Os2O4 6-membered ring motif. This H-bonding is evidenced by the O⋅⋅⋅H-O angle of 160(6)° and the O⋅⋅⋅O bond distance of 2.035 Å.

elements.content: Furthermore, these K2Os2O4 planar metallocycles are linked with each other through O(osmyl)–K+ (K1–O6 2.850(4) Å) interactions leading to the formation of infinite stepladder chains as shown in Figure B. These chains contact through hydrophobic interaction caused by the tert-butyl in the para position of the aromatic ring ().
elements.clean_text: Furthermore, these K2Os2O4 planar metallocycles are linked with each other through O(osmyl)-K+ (K1-O6 2.850(4) Å) interactions leading to the formation of infinite stepladder chains as shown in Figure B. These chains contact through hydrophobic interaction caused by the tert-butyl in the para position of the aromatic ring ().

elements.content: In Os 1 , the coordination of the ligand is similar to that in Os 2b , i.e., a planar trianionic NO2 chelating mode. However, the absence of a second pendant arm in 1LH3 allows the formation of an unprecedented μ-alkoxo-di-Os(VI) dioxo trianionic complex [(OsO2)2(1L)2(HO)]3– (Figure ). The dinuclear Os complex is unsymmetrical, as only one alcoholate pendant arm’s O atom (O5) bridges the two Os ions with bond lengths of 2.078(3) Å (Os1–O5) and 2.168(3) Å and (Os2–O5). The Os(1) ion is coordinated by an additional hydroxyl ligand O(4) with a bond distance of 2.194(3) Å, which in turn is H-bonded to the coordinated alcoholate O atom O9 (O4···O9 ca. 2.6 Å). In this dinuclear complex, the distance between the two osmium ions of 3.768 Å is much longer than that in OsO4(tBupy)4 reported by Mayer at al. (3.007(1) Å).
elements.clean_text:
[Os2O4(1L)2(OH)K2(H2O)(C3H6O)], Os  1  

In Os  1 , the coordination of the ligand is similar to that in Os  2b , i.e., a planar trianionic NO2 chelating mode. However, the absence of a second pendant arm in 1LH3 allows the formation of an unprecedented μ-alkoxo-di-Os(VI) dioxo trianionic complex [(OsO2)2(1L)2(HO)]3- (Figure ). The dinuclear Os complex is unsymmetrical, as only one alcoholate pendant arm's O atom (O5) bridges the two Os ions with bond lengths of 2.078(3) Å (Os1-O5) and 2.168(3) Å and (Os2-O5). The Os(1) ion is coordinated by an additional hydroxyl ligand O(4) with a bond distance of 2.194(3) Å, which in turn is H-bonded to the coordinated alcoholate O atom O9 (O4⋅⋅⋅O9 ca. 2.6 Å). In this dinuclear complex, the distance between the two osmium ions of 3.768 Å is much longer than that in OsO4(tBupy)4 reported by Mayer at al. (3.007(1) Å).

elements.content: The trianionic di-Os units are connected together through interactions with the two potassium counterions K1 and K2, along both c- and b-crystallographic axes, yielding the formation of a 2D grid network (Figure A). As shown in Figure B, the b-directed chain motifs are formed by interaction of each potassium ions (K1 and K2) with the two osmyl O atom pair (O1/O7 and O3/O8) located above and below the mean plane of the dinuclear units, respectively, with K–O distances ranging from 2.665(3) to 2.707 Å. One can note that K2 is further connected to the dinuclear unit through H-bonding between a water molecule (O14) and the Os-coordinated hydroxyl O atom (O4), as evidenced by the O14···O4 distance of ca. 2.8 Å.
elements.clean_text: The trianionic di-Os units are connected together through interactions with the two potassium counterions K1 and K2, along both c- and b-crystallographic axes, yielding the formation of a 2D grid network (Figure A). As shown in Figure B, the b-directed chain motifs are formed by interaction of each potassium ions (K1 and K2) with the two osmyl O atom pair (O1/O7 and O3/O8) located above and below the mean plane of the dinuclear units, respectively, with K-O distances ranging from 2.665(3) to 2.707 Å. One can note that K2 is further connected to the dinuclear unit through H-bonding between a water molecule (O14) and the Os-coordinated hydroxyl O atom (O4), as evidenced by the O14⋅⋅⋅O4 distance of ca. 2.8 Å.

elements.content: Both K1 and K2 are bridged by O atom of acetone (K1–O13 2.751(3); K2–O13 2.784(3) Å); with a distance between two potassium ions of ca. 3.72 Å. As shown in Figure C, the two potassium ions are further bridged by the CO amide O atoms (O11 and O12) from the coordinated ligands that link the complexes together along the c-axis with K–O bond distance of ca. 2.7–2.8 Å, which is in the range of those previously reported (2.658 Å). Thus, in this structure the di-K+ unit acts as a 2D-grid connector.
elements.clean_text: Both K1 and K2 are bridged by O atom of acetone (K1-O13 2.751(3); K2-O13 2.784(3) Å); with a distance between two potassium ions of ca. 3.72 Å. As shown in Figure C, the two potassium ions are further bridged by the CO amide O atoms (O11 and O12) from the coordinated ligands that link the complexes together along the c-axis with K-O bond distance of ca. 2.7-2.8 Å, which is in the range of those previously reported (2.658 Å). Thus, in this structure the di-K+ unit acts as a 2D-grid connector.

elements.content: The phenol-diamide pro-ligand 2aLH3 possesses two ethanolamine pendant arms as the 2bLH3 one but lacks methyl groups at the α-carbon atom. As for the structure of Os 2b , in Os 2a , only one pendant arm coordinates the osmyl in a planar NO2 fashion, while the other arm remains protonated. The two potassium atoms K1 and K2 bridge the osmyl complexes together along crystallographic b-axis, via osmyl-O6 and O7 atoms (K–O bond distances are in the range 2.831–3.17 Å), yielding infinite chains (Figure ). This structure is further stabilized by the bridging of the two potassium ions by O2S atom of a methanol molecule [with K1–O2S 2.782(2) Å and K2–O2S 2.694(2) Å] and by interactions between the other ligand’s oxygen atoms and the potassium ions, e.g., the alcoholate O1 atom [K1–O1 1.9970(19) Å], short contacts between K2 and alcohol atom O5 [K2–O5 3.0033(3) Å] and the amide atom N2 [K2–N2 3.299(3) Å]. Further, intramolecular H-bonding interactions are established between amide N2–H and the phenolate O3 atom [N2···O3 2.576(3) Å; N2–H···O3 135(3)°] and pendant alcohol O5–H and methanol O(1S) atom [O5–H···O1S 2.709(3) Å; O5–H···O1S 172(3)°] (Figure ).
elements.clean_text:
[OsO2(2aL3-)(MeOH)4(MeO)K2] Os  2a  

The phenol-diamide pro-ligand 2aLH3 possesses two ethanolamine pendant arms as the 2bLH3 one but lacks methyl groups at the α-carbon atom. As for the structure of Os  2b , in Os  2a , only one pendant arm coordinates the osmyl in a planar NO2 fashion, while the other arm remains protonated. The two potassium atoms K1 and K2 bridge the osmyl complexes together along crystallographic b-axis, via osmyl-O6 and O7 atoms (K-O bond distances are in the range 2.831-3.17 Å), yielding infinite chains (Figure ). This structure is further stabilized by the bridging of the two potassium ions by O2S atom of a methanol molecule [with K1-O2S 2.782(2) Å and K2-O2S 2.694(2) Å] and by interactions between the other ligand's oxygen atoms and the potassium ions, e.g., the alcoholate O1 atom [K1-O1 1.9970(19) Å], short contacts between K2 and alcohol atom O5 [K2-O5 3.0033(3) Å] and the amide atom N2 [K2-N2 3.299(3) Å]. Further, intramolecular H-bonding interactions are established between amide N2-H and the phenolate O3 atom [N2⋅⋅⋅O3 2.576(3) Å; N2-H⋅⋅⋅O3 135(3)°] and pendant alcohol O5-H and methanol O(1S) atom [O5-H⋅⋅⋅O1S 2.709(3) Å; O5-H⋅⋅⋅O1S 172(3)°] (Figure ).

elements.content: The [010] chain motifs are linked together via intermolecular interactions between the potassium ions K1 and K2 and the carbonyl atoms O2 and O4 [K1–O2 2.619(2) Å, K2–O4 2.593(2) Å]. These interactions allow the formation of 2D sheet as shown in Figure . The sheets are further linked together by hydrogen bonds between the K1-coordinated methanol O atoms O4S and O5S [O4S···O5S 2.831(5) Å, O4S–H···O5S 177.3°], to yield an unprecedented 3D-network which comprises tubular pores with a diameter of ca. 18 nm (Figure ).
elements.clean_text: The [010] chain motifs are linked together via intermolecular interactions between the potassium ions K1 and K2 and the carbonyl atoms O2 and O4 [K1-O2 2.619(2) Å, K2-O4 2.593(2) Å]. These interactions allow the formation of 2D sheet as shown in Figure . The sheets are further linked together by hydrogen bonds between the K1-coordinated methanol O atoms O4S and O5S [O4S⋅⋅⋅O5S 2.831(5) Å, O4S-H⋅⋅⋅O5S 177.3°], to yield an unprecedented 3D-network which comprises tubular pores with a diameter of ca. 18 nm (Figure ).

elements.content:
The topological analysis of 1D (Os 2b ) and 2D (Os 1 and Os 2a ) coordination polymers has been carried out using TOPOS software package following the concept of the simplified underlying net.

For stepladder 1D Os 2b chains, both the μ3-2bL and μ-H2O moieties have been reduced to their centroids and the acetone (O9) ligand was omitted. The network of Os 2b can be described as an underlying net (Figure ) built from the 4-connected K1 and 3-connected Os1 nodes, the 3-connected μ3-2bL nodes, the 2-connected μ-oxo atoms O6 and O7, and the μ-H2O (O8) linkers. The resulting underlying net consists of a trinodal 3,4-connected network with a an unprecedented topology described by the point symbol (3.4.5.6.7.8)(3.4.5)(3.6.7), wherein the notations (3.4.5.6.7.8), (3.4.5), and (3.6.7) correspond to the K1, μ3-2bL, and Os1 nodes, respectively. It should be noted that new topological types are rarely encountered in 1D coordination networks.
elements.clean_text:
Topological Analysis

The topological analysis of 1D (Os  2b ) and 2D (Os  1  and Os  2a ) coordination polymers has been carried out using TOPOS software package following the concept of the simplified underlying net. 

For stepladder 1D Os  2b  chains, both the μ3-2bL and μ-H2O moieties have been reduced to their centroids and the acetone (O9) ligand was omitted. The network of Os  2b  can be described as an underlying net (Figure ) built from the 4-connected K1 and 3-connected Os1 nodes, the 3-connected μ3-2bL nodes, the 2-connected μ-oxo atoms O6 and O7, and the μ-H2O (O8) linkers. The resulting underlying net consists of a trinodal 3,4-connected network with a an unprecedented topology described by the point symbol (3.4.5.6.7.8)(3.4.5)(3.6.7), wherein the notations (3.4.5.6.7.8), (3.4.5), and (3.6.7) correspond to the K1, μ3-2bL, and Os1 nodes, respectively. It should be noted that new topological types are rarely encountered in 1D coordination networks.

elements.content: Topological representation of the underlying stepladder 1D network in Os 2b : front (a) and side (b) views of the trinodal 3,4-connected net. Color codes: centroids of μ3-2bL (cyan), Os1 (purple), and K1 (magenta) nodes, and μ-oxo O6 and O7, and μ-H2O O8 (red) linkers.
elements.clean_text: 6  Topological representation of the underlying stepladder 1D network in Os  2b : front (a) and side (b) views of the trinodal 3,4-connected net. Color codes: centroids of μ3-2bL (cyan), Os1 (purple), and K1 (magenta) nodes, and μ-oxo O6 and O7, and μ-H2O O8 (red) linkers.

elements.content: For 2D Os 2a network, the μ5-2aL and μ-MeOH (O1S) ligands have been reduced to their centroids and MeOH moieties (O1S, O4S, O5S) have been omitted resulting in an underlying network (Figure ) composed of the 5-connected K1, K2, and μ5-2aL nodes, 3-connected Os1, μ3-oxo O6 and O7 nodes, and 2-connected μ-MeOH linkers. The resulting hexanodal 3,5-connected net features an unprecedented topology with the point symbol of (3.4.5)2(32.42.53.63)(32.43.5.63.7)(42.6)(43.52.64.7), wherein the notations (3.4.5), (32.42.53.63), (32.43.5.63.7), (42.6), and (43.52.64.7) are those of the μ3-oxo O6/O7 (topologically similar), K1, K2, Os1, and μ5-2aL nodes, respectively.
elements.clean_text: For 2D Os  2a  network, the μ5-2aL and μ-MeOH (O1S) ligands have been reduced to their centroids and MeOH moieties (O1S, O4S, O5S) have been omitted resulting in an underlying network (Figure ) composed of the 5-connected K1, K2, and μ5-2aL nodes, 3-connected Os1, μ3-oxo O6 and O7 nodes, and 2-connected μ-MeOH linkers. The resulting hexanodal 3,5-connected net features an unprecedented topology with the point symbol of (3.4.5)2(32.42.53.63)(32.43.5.63.7)(42.6)(43.52.64.7), wherein the notations (3.4.5), (32.42.53.63), (32.43.5.63.7), (42.6), and (43.52.64.7) are those of the μ3-oxo O6/O7 (topologically similar), K1, K2, Os1, and μ5-2aL nodes, respectively.

elements.content: Topological representation of the underlying 2D network in Os 2a : front (a) and side (b) views of the hexanodal 3,5-connected net. Color codes: centroids of μ5-2aL (cyan), K1 and K2 (magenta), Os1 (purple), μ3-oxo O6 and O7 (red) nodes, and μ-MeOH(O1S) (yellow) linkers.
elements.clean_text: 7  Topological representation of the underlying 2D network in Os  2a : front (a) and side (b) views of the hexanodal 3,5-connected net. Color codes: centroids of μ5-2aL (cyan), K1 and K2 (magenta), Os1 (purple), μ3-oxo O6 and O7 (red) nodes, and μ-MeOH(O1S) (yellow) linkers.

elements.content: Topological representation of the underlying 2D network in Os 1 : front (a) and side (b) views of the hexanodal 3,4,5,6-connected net. Color codes: centroids of K2 and K1 (magenta), μ4-1L (cyan), and Os2 and Os1 (purple) nodes, and μ-acetone (O13) (yellow), μ-oxo O1, O3, O7, and O8 (red) linkers.
elements.clean_text: 8  Topological representation of the underlying 2D network in Os  1 : front (a) and side (b) views of the hexanodal 3,4,5,6-connected net. Color codes: centroids of K2 and K1 (magenta), μ4-1L (cyan), and Os2 and Os1 (purple) nodes, and μ-acetone (O13) (yellow), μ-oxo O1, O3, O7, and O8 (red) linkers.

elements.content: The topological analysis of the simplified underlying 2D network of Os 1 also reveals a hexanodal net. It is, however, a different 3,4,5,6-connected network (Figure ) constructed from the 6-connected K1 and 5-connected K2 nodes, 4-connected Os2 and 3-connected Os1 nodes, two 4-connected μ4-1L topologically distinct nodes, as well as 2-connected μ-acetone (O13) and four μ-oxo (O1, O3, O7, O8) linkers. This net reveals a novel type of topology with the point symbol of (3.4.64)(3.43.52)(32.42.5.64.7)(32.52.62)(33.42.52.64.73.8)(43), wherein the notations (3.4.64), (3.43.52), (32.42.5.64.7), (32.52.62), (33.42.52.64.73.8), and (43) correspond to μ4-1L, Os2, K2, μ4-1L, K1, and Os1 nodes, respectively. Only a few examples of hexanodal networks have recently been reported.
elements.clean_text: The topological analysis of the simplified underlying 2D network of Os  1  also reveals a hexanodal net. It is, however, a different 3,4,5,6-connected network (Figure ) constructed from the 6-connected K1 and 5-connected K2 nodes, 4-connected Os2 and 3-connected Os1 nodes, two 4-connected μ4-1L topologically distinct nodes, as well as 2-connected μ-acetone (O13) and four μ-oxo (O1, O3, O7, O8) linkers. This net reveals a novel type of topology with the point symbol of (3.4.64)(3.43.52)(32.42.5.64.7)(32.52.62)(33.42.52.64.73.8)(43), wherein the notations (3.4.64), (3.43.52), (32.42.5.64.7), (32.52.62), (33.42.52.64.73.8), and (43) correspond to μ4-1L, Os2, K2, μ4-1L, K1, and Os1 nodes, respectively. Only a few examples of hexanodal networks have recently been reported.

elements.content: We have reported the first crystallographically characterized examples of trans-dioxoosmium(VI) derivatives bearing polyanionic salicylamidate ligands. These structures have revealed unprecedented features of osmyl coordination abilities toward MOFs. In spite of the close structural resemblance of the pro-ligands used and their similar NO2 trianionic coordination modes to the osmyl moiety; the corresponding Os/K networks formed show distinct architectures, ranging from stepladder chain (in Os 2b ) and 2D-grid (in Os 1 and Os 2a ) MOFs to 3D-porous H-bonding network (in Os 2a ). These networks are formed by the assembling of anionic osmium complexes and coordinating K+ cations, through O-carbonyl ligands and osmyl-oxo ligands that adopt different bridging modes. Their topological analysis revealed unprecedented trinodal 3,4-connected (Os 2b ) and hexanodal 3,5- (Os 2a ) or 3,4,5,6-connected (Os 1 ) underlying nets. Hence, the present work also contributes to the identification and classification of coordination polymers with new topologies. The catalytic activity of these new materials is being investigated in our laboratories.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

We have reported the first crystallographically characterized examples of trans-dioxoosmium(VI) derivatives bearing polyanionic salicylamidate ligands. These structures have revealed unprecedented features of osmyl coordination abilities toward MOFs. In spite of the close structural resemblance of the pro-ligands used and their similar NO2 trianionic coordination modes to the osmyl moiety; the corresponding Os/K networks formed show distinct architectures, ranging from stepladder chain (in Os  2b ) and 2D-grid (in Os  1  and Os  2a ) MOFs to 3D-porous H-bonding network (in Os  2a ). These networks are formed by the assembling of anionic osmium complexes and coordinating K+ cations, through O-carbonyl ligands and osmyl-oxo ligands that adopt different bridging modes. Their topological analysis revealed unprecedented trinodal 3,4-connected (Os  2b ) and hexanodal 3,5- (Os  2a ) or 3,4,5,6-connected (Os  1 ) underlying nets. Hence, the present work also contributes to the identification and classification of coordination polymers with new topologies. The catalytic activity of these new materials is being investigated in our laboratories.

metadata.title:
Os(VI)O2/K
Metal–Organic Frameworks:
Infinite Chain, Grid, and Porous Networks
